design.title: Dise√±o
paragraphs: I'm a software developer and I love design, to the point that I cannot conceive one without the other, in the same way that you could not conceive physical design without the material that makes it possible. Even though I cannot call myself a designer (I have too much respect for design to do so), I love to make my attempts on designing stuff, or at least implement design guidelines that I'm fond of. It‚Äôs because of that, that I decided to design my own website.

My intention was to create a website that checked these items in this order: 1) has to be accessible, 2) has to put the content front and center, moving non-essential elements out of the way and hiding the complexity, 3) has to be simple to get through, and finally, 4) has to be aesthetically pleasing.

I started by carefully choosing the layout, since I understand it is a basic part of the design, and that this decision will, later on, either facilitate my job, or make it harder than it should be. I decided to have three elements to handle three functionalities, three elements to compete for the users attention, three elements to worry about.

First the content, it‚Äôs presence takes the whole canvas by being a centered vertical strip floating in a background with no interruptions. This is also a simple recourse to support mobile and desktop screens. And yes, I prefer to design desktop-first, I'm crazy like that ü§™.

Then we have the navigation menu that sits in a corner with minimal presence, some color to indicate active status along with a border for [accessibility reasons](https://www.w3.org/TR/UNDERSTANDING-WCAG20/visual-audio-contrast-without-color.html), and a behavior that allows it to be collapsed onto it‚Äôs top level elements (not my original idea, but one that pays off).

And third, there‚Äôs a contact and information footer that overlays on top of the content, while fuses with the background. That was my way of saying ‚ÄúThis is me, feel free to reach out‚Äù, without hiding the message while keeping it out of the way of the content.

A big part of the pleasing sight of this site are the amazing illustrations used to accompany these words, and I would like to thank [unDraw](https://undraw.co/) for making all that open source content available to everyone.
I will mention that the design is fully responsive, but I won‚Äôt get into details because, honestly, that should be a given nowadays.

Finally, and to be clear, I am not trying to sell you this design, I‚Äôm just being explicit about intention and decision making, so you can know I didn‚Äôt just take someone else‚Äôs design, and to have a guide for myself for future interventions.

performance.title: Desempe√±o
paragraphs: Currently this site doesn‚Äôt do much to improve performance, it mostly implements passive methods like avoiding heavy assets and unnecessary libraries.

To improve loading times I‚Äôm using code splitting by routes, this way the site will only load the content of the selected view, along with the navigation and footer, helping the load performance and making the site feel faster.

Testing with [Lighthouse](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse) this site reaches 97/100 on performance which is enough for most apps, and I consider it to be more than enough for a site like this. I will attempt to reach 100/100, which I know is overkill, but since I‚Äôm not spending someone‚Äôs money, and don‚Äôt even have a deadline, there‚Äôs no reason no to do it.

I have a sort of roadmap to continue the work on this subject that includes: using a service worker to cache all assets so they will be requested as little as possible, (other superpowers enabled by service workers, like making an installable app or receiving notifications, have no use case in this site so they won‚Äôt be used), optimization of images taking advantage of [Squoosh.app](https://squoosh.app/), while also providing different image sizes for different screen sizes, and maybe, transition to server side rendering.

tech.title: Tecnolog√≠a
paragraphs: Although tech was not the last thing I thought about, it is the last one to be mentioned because it should be out of the way.
These are the more relevant technologies involved with this site:
[HTML5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML5), page structuring and articulation of the other technologies involved.
[JavaScript](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JavaScript), primarily used to build the user interface in the client side, also makes possible the interaction of the users with the page.
[CSS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascading_Style_Sheets), defines and applies the styles and animations that enrich the interaction of users with the site.
[React](https://facebook.github.io/react/), its a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. Through this library is that JavaScript build the user interface.
[Redux](https://redux.js.org/), its a predictable state container for JavaScript applications. Used to handle language state and general app info.

[Webpack](https://webpack.js.org/), bundling and minification of JavaScript and CSS files as well as other resources, to optimize the resource loading. In the case of this page it is used from the React scripts.
